_**The Chronicles of Narnia**_ is a series of films based on _[The Chronicles
of Narnia](/wiki/The_Chronicles_of_Narnia "The Chronicles of Narnia")_ , a
series of novels by [C. S. Lewis](/wiki/C._S._Lewis "C. S. Lewis"). From the
seven novels, there have been three film adaptations so far— _[The Lion, the
Witch and the
Wardrobe](/wiki/The_Chronicles_of_Narnia:_The_Lion,_the_Witch_and_the_Wardrobe
"The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe")_ (2005),
_[Prince Caspian](/wiki/The_Chronicles_of_Narnia:_Prince_Caspian "The
Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian")_ (2008) and _[The Voyage of the Dawn
Treader](/wiki/The_Chronicles_of_Narnia:_The_Voyage_of_the_Dawn_Treader "The
Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader")_ (2010)—which have
grossed over $1.5 billion worldwide among them.

The series revolves around the adventures of children in the world of
[Narnia](/wiki/Narnia_\(world\) "Narnia \(world\)"), guided by
[Aslan](/wiki/Aslan "Aslan"), a wise and powerful lion that can speak and is
the true king of Narnia. The children heavily featured in the films are the
Pevensie siblings, and a prominent antagonist is the [White
Witch](/wiki/White_Witch "White Witch") (also known as Jadis).

The first two films were directed by [Andrew Adamson](/wiki/Andrew_Adamson
"Andrew Adamson") and the third film was directed by [Michael
Apted](/wiki/Michael_Apted "Michael Apted"). The fourth film will be directed
by [Joe Johnston](/wiki/Joe_Johnston "Joe Johnston").

##
Development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Chronicles_of_Narnia_\(film_series\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Development")]

C. S. Lewis never sold the film rights to the _Narnia_ series during his
lifetime, as he was skeptical that any cinematic adaptation could render the
more fantastical elements and characters of the story realistically.[a] Only
after seeing a demo reel of [CGI](/wiki/Computer-generated_imagery "Computer-
generated imagery") animals did [Douglas Gresham](/wiki/Douglas_Gresham
"Douglas Gresham") (Lewis's stepson and [literary
executor](/wiki/Literary_executor "Literary executor"), and film co-producer)
give approval for a film adaptation.

Although the plan was originally to produce the films in the same order as the
book series' original publication, it was reported that _[The Magician's
Nephew](/wiki/The_Magician%27s_Nephew "The Magician's Nephew")_, which
recounts the creation of Narnia, would be the fourth feature film in the
series, instead of _[The Silver Chair](/wiki/The_Silver_Chair "The Silver
Chair")_. It was rumoured that _The Magician 's Nephew_ was chosen as an
attempt to reboot the series, after the release of _The Voyage of the Dawn
Treader_ grossed less when compared to the two previous films.[1] In March
2011, Walden Media confirmed that they intended _The Magician 's Nephew_ to be
next in the series, but stressed that it was not yet in development.[2]

In October 2011, Douglas Gresham stated that Walden Media's contract with the
C. S. Lewis estate had expired, hinting that Walden Media's lapse in
renegotiating their contract with the C. S. Lewis estate was due to internal
conflicts between both companies about the direction of future films.[3]

On 1 October 2013, The C. S. Lewis Company announced a partnership with [The
Mark Gordon Company](/wiki/The_Mark_Gordon_Company "The Mark Gordon Company"),
and that _The Chronicles of Narnia: The Silver Chair_ was officially in pre-
production.[4]

##
Films[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Chronicles_of_Narnia_\(film_series\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Films")]

### _The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe_
(2005)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Chronicles_of_Narnia_\(film_series\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe \(2005\)")]

Main article: [The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the
Wardrobe](/wiki/The_Chronicles_of_Narnia:_The_Lion,_the_Witch_and_the_Wardrobe
"The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe")

[_The Lion, the Witch and the
Wardrobe_](/wiki/The_Chronicles_of_Narnia:_The_Lion,_the_Witch_and_the_Wardrobe
"The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe"), based on
the [novel of the same title](/wiki/The_Lion,_the_Witch_and_the_Wardrobe "The
Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe"), is the first film in the series. Directed
by Andrew Adamson, it was shot mainly in New Zealand, though locations were
used in Poland, the [Czech Republic](/wiki/Czech_Republic "Czech Republic")
and the United Kingdom.

The story follows the four British [Pevensie](/wiki/Pevensie "Pevensie")
siblings, who are evacuated during [the Blitz](/wiki/The_Blitz "The Blitz") to
the countryside, where they find a wardrobe that leads to the [fantasy
world](/wiki/Fantasy_world "Fantasy world") of [Narnia](/wiki/Narnia_\(world\)
"Narnia \(world\)"). There, they must ally with the lion [Aslan](/wiki/Aslan
"Aslan") against the forces of the [White Witch](/wiki/White_Witch "White
Witch"), who has placed Narnia in an eternal winter.

The film was released theatrically on 9 December 2005 and on DVD on 4 April
2006 and grossed over $745 million worldwide.

### _Prince Caspian_
(2008)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Chronicles_of_Narnia_\(film_series\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Prince Caspian \(2008\)")]

Main article: [The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince
Caspian](/wiki/The_Chronicles_of_Narnia:_Prince_Caspian "The Chronicles of
Narnia: Prince Caspian")

[_Prince Caspian_](/wiki/The_Chronicles_of_Narnia:_Prince_Caspian "The
Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian"), based on the [novel of the same
title](/wiki/Prince_Caspian "Prince Caspian"), is the second film in the
series and the last distributed by [Walt Disney
Pictures](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Pictures "Walt Disney Pictures").

The story follows the same Pevensie children who were transported to Narnia in
the [previous
film](/wiki/The_Chronicles_of_Narnia:_The_Lion,_the_Witch_and_the_Wardrobe
"The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe") as they
return to Narnia, where 1,300 years have passed and the land has been invaded
by the [Telmarines](/wiki/Telmarines "Telmarines"). The four Pevensie children
aid [Prince Caspian](/wiki/Caspian_X "Caspian X") in his struggle for the
throne against his corrupt uncle, King [Miraz](/wiki/Miraz "Miraz").

The film was released on 16 May 2008. It grossed $419 million worldwide.

### _The Voyage of the Dawn Treader_
(2010)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Chronicles_of_Narnia_\(film_series\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader \(2010\)")]

Main article: [The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn
Treader](/wiki/The_Chronicles_of_Narnia:_The_Voyage_of_the_Dawn_Treader "The
Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader")

_[The Voyage of the Dawn
Treader](/wiki/The_Chronicles_of_Narnia:_The_Voyage_of_the_Dawn_Treader "The
Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader")_ , based on the [novel
of the same title](/wiki/The_Voyage_of_the_Dawn_Treader "The Voyage of the
Dawn Treader"), is the first film in the series not to be co-produced by
[Disney](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Pictures "Walt Disney Pictures"), who dropped out
over a budget dispute with [Walden Media](/wiki/Walden_Media "Walden Media").
In February 2009 it was announced that [20th Century
Fox](/wiki/20th_Century_Fox "20th Century Fox") would replace Disney for
future installments. Directed by Michael Apted, the movie was filmed almost
entirely in Australia.

The story follows the two younger Pevensie children as they return to Narnia
with their cousin, [Eustace Scrubb](/wiki/Eustace_Scrubb "Eustace Scrubb").
They join the old king of Narnia, Caspian, in his quest to rescue seven lost
lords and save Narnia from a corrupting evil that resides on a lit island.[5]

The film was released on 10 December 2010 (in [RealD 3D](/wiki/RealD_3D "RealD
3D") in select theatres) and grossed over $415 million worldwide.

### _The Silver
Chair_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Chronicles_of_Narnia_\(film_series\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: The Silver Chair")]

After Walden Media's contract of the series' film rights expired in 2011 it
was originally assumed that 2014 would be the earliest that production on
another _Narnia_ film could begin according to the
[moratorium](/wiki/Moratorium_\(law\) "Moratorium \(law\)") placed on the C.
S. Lewis estate's right to sell the books' film option.

On 1 October 2013, The C. S. Lewis Company announced that it had entered into
an agreement with the Mark Gordon Company to produce _The Chronicles of
Narnia: The Silver Chair_ , based on _[The Silver
Chair](/wiki/The_Silver_Chair "The Silver Chair")_. [Mark
Gordon](/wiki/Mark_Gordon "Mark Gordon") and [Douglas
Gresham](/wiki/Douglas_Gresham "Douglas Gresham") along with Vincent Sieber,
the [Los Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles") based director of The C. S.
Lewis Company, would serve as producers and work with The Mark Gordon Company
on developing the script.[4] On 5 December 2013, it was announced that [David
Magee](/wiki/David_Magee "David Magee") would write the screenplay.[6]

In July 2014, the official Narnia website allowed the opportunity for fans to
suggest names for the [Lady of the Green
Kirtle](/wiki/Lady_of_the_Green_Kirtle "Lady of the Green Kirtle"), the main
antagonist. The winning name is to be selected by Mark Gordon and David Magee
for use in the final script of _The Chronicles of Narnia: The Silver
Chair_.[7]

While the film's producers have been calling the film a "reboot" to the
series, in actuality this is referring to the fact that the film has a new
creative team not associated with those who worked on the previous three
films. The film itself is still considered to be a sequel to the film
adaptation of _The Voyage of the Dawn Treader_.[8][9] On 9 August 2016, it was
announced that [Sony](/wiki/Sony_Pictures "Sony Pictures")'s [TriStar
Productions](/wiki/TriStar_Productions "TriStar Productions") and
[Entertainment One Films](/wiki/Entertainment_One_Films "Entertainment One
Films") will finance and distribute the fourth film with Mark Gordon Company
(which eOne owns) and C. S. Lewis Company.[10]

In April 2017, it was announced that [Joe Johnston](/wiki/Joe_Johnston "Joe
Johnston") had been hired to direct _The Silver Chair_.[11] In October,
Johnston said filming is expected to begin in late 2018.[12]

During an interview with _Red Carpet News TV_ , producer Mark Gordon revealed
scarce details about the new technologies and setting that would be used for
the upcoming film, but did not give a release date.[13]

## Main
cast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Chronicles_of_Narnia_\(film_series\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Main cast")]

###
Children[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Chronicles_of_Narnia_\(film_series\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Children")]

  * [William Moseley](/wiki/William_Moseley_\(actor\) "William Moseley \(actor\)") as [Peter Pevensie](/wiki/Peter_Pevensie "Peter Pevensie"), title: High King Peter the Magnificent, the eldest Pevensie child and the High King of Narnia during the Golden Age.
  * [Anna Popplewell](/wiki/Anna_Popplewell "Anna Popplewell") as [Susan Pevensie](/wiki/Susan_Pevensie "Susan Pevensie"), title: Queen Susan the Gentle, the elder Pevensie child and a Queen of Narnia during the Golden Age.
  * [Skandar Keynes](/wiki/Skandar_Keynes "Skandar Keynes") as [Edmund Pevensie](/wiki/Edmund_Pevensie "Edmund Pevensie"), title: King Edmund the Just; the younger Pevensie child and a King of Narnia during the Golden Age.
  * [Georgie Henley](/wiki/Georgie_Henley "Georgie Henley") as [Lucy Pevensie](/wiki/Lucy_Pevensie "Lucy Pevensie"), title: Queen Lucy the Valiant, the youngest Pevensie child and a Queen of Narnia during the Golden Age.
  * [Will Poulter](/wiki/Will_Poulter "Will Poulter") as [Eustace Scrubb](/wiki/Eustace_Scrubb "Eustace Scrubb"), the Pevensie children's arrogant cousin. He will return to Narnia with his friend Jill Pole in _The Silver Chair._

### Other Main
Characters[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Chronicles_of_Narnia_\(film_series\)&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Other Main Characters")]

  * [Liam Neeson](/wiki/Liam_Neeson "Liam Neeson") as the voice of [Aslan](/wiki/Aslan "Aslan"), the magnificent and majestically powerful lion who helps govern and maintain order in Narnia; a mystical world of his own creation. He is the only main character to appear in all seven books.
  * [Tilda Swinton](/wiki/Tilda_Swinton "Tilda Swinton") as Jadis, the [White Witch](/wiki/White_Witch "White Witch"); the former queen of Charn and a witch who ruled Narnia after being released in _The Magician 's Nephew_ and during the events of _The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe_.
  * [Ben Barnes](/wiki/Ben_Barnes_\(actor\) "Ben Barnes \(actor\)") as [Caspian X](/wiki/Caspian_X "Caspian X") (Also known as "Prince Caspian"), the Telmarine prince who becomes King of Narnia after overthrowing his evil uncle [Miraz](/wiki/Miraz "Miraz").
  * [Eddie Izzard](/wiki/Eddie_Izzard "Eddie Izzard") and [Simon Pegg](/wiki/Simon_Pegg "Simon Pegg") as the voice of [Reepicheep](/wiki/Reepicheep "Reepicheep") in _Prince Caspian_ and _The Voyage of the Dawn Treader_ , respectively. The noble and courageous mouse who fights for Aslan and the freedom of Narnia.
